comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here it is in colour: www.myhometown.ie/130/The_Girls_Home_of_Rest/1476.html

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Possibly featured in the Newtonards Chronicle as "foundation stone of Seaside Home of Rest for Working Girls 19 Aug 1893"

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: Here's the Wikipedia entry for the Girl's Friendly Society- en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Girls'_Friendly_Society , it sounds like it could be quite a useful organisation, even today!?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
NOTICE is hereby given, pursuant to the Statute
30 and 31 Vic. Cap. 54, that the above-named
testator, by her Will, dated the 4th day of March,
1940, after a certain pecuniary bequest and payment
of her debts, funeral and testamentary expenses,
directed that one moiety of the residue of her estate
should be paid to the Girls' Home of Rest at
Bangor, Co. Down, in connection with the Cripples'
Institute, People's Palace and Home of Rest, and
the remaining moiety to the Old Age Fund of the
Presbyterian Church in Ireland.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: eppi.dippam.ac.uk/documents/21026/eppi_pages/582743 They got £50, 5, - off the government to run the place in 1905, apparently.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The foundation stone was laid on august 17th 1893 and attended by the whole world's grandads and their dog, if geneaology sites are anything to go by.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/adambangor/4319857650/

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Oh I am just outside Bangor! There were a number of "Barnardo's homes" in Bangor west in the Strickland's glen area and indeed a number of the buildings still exist. Off to hunt!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content:
I think one building has been replaced by the Stewart Memorial Home in Downshire Road Bangor, but that is only in the last 10 or 15 years as remember the buildings well. 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] My memory from local history is that there were two - one for boys and one for girls!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: I came across this freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~rosdavies/SURN... A Mr Vance (of Bangor) "a philanthropist who financed 3 rest homes in Downshire Road, Bangor, for Belfast's deprived". c1899

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: There are photographs of these buildings in several photographic collections - I think Hogg is one of them.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] As a local, can you identify the buildings in the background (e.g. the cupola) and so locate the home?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/adambangor/2398433711/ This has the 3 properties that I remember.

comment.author: 84511729@N00
comment._content: There's an odd looking spire or tower or something in the background at far left. Does that help?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The 1939 OSNI map has 3 homes of rest marked at the West end of Downshire road.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: And one on Brompton Road...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The map also marks something called Glenbank Tower over at Seacourt to the NE of those homes

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You can view the OSNI historical maps at this link

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
I don't think it could be any of those ones. The profile's are wrong and it would put the sun coming from the north.

Edit: Actually, it would be from the west. That seems more plausible. It looks most like the Brompton Road one then, I think.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] There are a number of VERY large homes of the gentry that were built along the shore here and although I can't place that wee spire I think it is a feature in the huge wall along the shore below these properties. It is possibly part of Thalassa, not Seacourt. Unfortunately Thalassa has been demolished in recent years.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That tower would be the right direction but the top on this does not look right.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] It has a cross on it. I assumed it was a church. It's quite blurred though, so it's hard to tell how far it is. It does look like it could just be a turret on a wall.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I suspect this may be the remains of it: maps.google.com/maps?q=Brompton+Road,+Bangor,+United+King...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If you pan left, you can see the tower, It is just a bit of wall.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: And here's the crennellated walls in the background. maps.google.com/maps?q=Brompton+Road,+Bangor,+United+King...

comment.author: 30622421@N03
30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Bingo - that is the wall!! (I just don't know how to  link to google maps..duh!) There is no church any where in that locality - you would be looking seawards.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I think it's more likely to be where Strickland's Bay is now. I think the tower would still be visible in the background and the distance looks about right. Also there is one remaining building on the Strickland's Bay site (on Downshire Lane) which looks contemporaneous with the Rest Home building. maps.google.ie/maps?q=Downshire+Ln,+Bangor,+County+Down+B...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That old OS Map indicates another tower closer to Brompton Road in addition to the one attached to the crenelated wall which could be the one in this photo

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's a shot from the nli archive of the 3 houses of rest in Vab's postcard, at the West end of Downshire road. I did think this might be the middle one, but from the other archive shot, you can see it is none of these three. So, not Stricklands... The rest home on Brompton Road was here (streetview), but it's a modern bungalow now.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: I am nearly sure that the roof between the wee spire/tower and the home is the roof of Seacourt which means this is the tower on the perimeter wall of Seacourt.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I saw that but it's the wrong shape and the paths and terraces in the main photo don't match the OSNI map.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You are good at this! That would put it closer to that tower and Seacourt.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Brompton Road it is! The "tower" is more of a pillar, but it is still there: Streetview

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: From the Gazeteer again - "the tower... at the bottom of Brompton Road, was built to watch yacht racing".

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Well played!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: And yes, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] , the corner of the big house you can see between the rest home and the pillar must be Seacourt.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: This is as close as I can get to matching the view point maps.google.com/maps?q=Brompton+Road,+Bangor,+United+King... The bungalow is positioned further forward on the site and a bit further north so it is obscuring the view of the tower but the topography matches.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The maps are no help for dating: the home of rest is on the 1919 and 1939 map, but not the 1895 map.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I've noted what looks like an electrical or telephone cable at the corner of the building. Urban electrification started in Ireland in 1880 so that doesn't help much with the date either.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The 1913 telephone directory lists 3 homes:

Bangor 36 Homes of Rest (Cripples' and Men's)
Bangor 78 Homes of Rest (Girls')
Bangor 29 Homes of Rest (Mothers')

which may be the Stricklands homes...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A page from the Census of 1911, showing all four homes, showing Josephine Faran in charge of the Girls Rest Home. Hmm, their ages are not very girlish.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Perhaps they are all being reported together here, the anonymized residents are male and female, from 5 to 50.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Well, this is the cripples home at any rate.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is Anna Louisa Faran, running a home of rest on Maxwell Road in 1901! And Josephine, too! Brompton Road is about as near to Maxwell Road as it is to Downshire road, so maybe the pictured home was counted on Maxwell Road in 1901 and Downshire Road in 1911. Sisters? One running the Girl's home, and the other the Men's here in 1901

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: Shades of Picnic at Hanging Rock about that image...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Really interesting mix of religions on those census returns! Had never seen Exclusive Brethren before.
